https://prez.dev/description.@value: The point or level from which heights and depths are measured and referenced to for an entity or activity. Typically these are expressed relative to a common global or regional reference datum such as the Australian Height Datum (AHD) or can be related to local reference systems. Specific emphasis is placed on elevation references used by resource exploration and drilling programs, whereby depths are measured relative to local reference datums or specific parts of a borehole/drilling platform. Concepts in this vocabulary include both reference datums (e.g. mean sea level) and how depths are expressed relative to them (e.g. mean sea level height).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The Australian Height Datum (AHD) is the vertical datum to which all height measurements are referred to in Australia. Adopted in 1971, the datum surface is that which passes through mean sea level (MSL) at the 30 tide gauges around the coast of the Australian continent as determined in 1966–68. AHD is considered fit for purpose for tasks over short distances (less than about 10 km) for projects such as cadastral, civil engineering, construction and mining; however, the Australian Vertical Working Surface (AVWS) has been defined to assist users working over larger areas (greater than about 10 km) for environmental studies (e.g. flood, storm modelling), LiDAR surveys, geodesy, hydrography.

AHD is considered fit for purpose for tasks over short distances (less than about 10 km) for projects such as cadastral, civil engineering, construction and mining; however, the Australian Vertical Working Surface (AVWS) has been defined to assist users working over larger areas (greater than about 10 km) for environmental studies (e.g. flood, storm modelling), LiDAR surveys, geodesy, hydrography.
